article.headline: Colorado 84, Colorado State 78
article.story: FORT COLLINS, Colo. (AP) -- There was more at stake than bragging rights when Colorado took on Colorado State on Wednesday night. There a score to settle between the teams' 7-foot centers. Colorado's David Harrison won the battle of the big men with 19 points and eight rebounds as CU defeated CSU 84-78. His counterpart, Matt Nelson, had nine points for Colorado State. "Last year Nelson killed," said Harrison, who was outscored 23-15 in the 2002 games against CSU. "I let him have some angles, and I wasn't going to let him have them this time." "David certainly makes a difference for us," Colorado coach Ricardo Patton said. "I think Nelson makes a difference for them as well." Harrison was 7-for-12 shooting with three big dunks for Colorado (5-1). "I can't say enough about the way he played me," Harrison said about Nelson. "He worked me. I had to work for everything I got tonight, but we won." Matt Williams had 26 points and 10 rebounds for Colorado State (4-3). Michel Morandais had 17 points for Colorado. "If you take Harrison out of the game, it's dead even," Colorado State coach Dale Layer said. "We hurt ourselves with scoring lapses, and you can't have the two or three we had against a good team like Colorado." Colorado broke the game open at the start of the second half with an 11-4 run that included a baby hook and a two-handed dunk by Harrison, giving the Buffaloes a 53-42 lead. Williams hit two layups to bring Colorado State to within 69-61, but Morandais hit four free throws, the second two after a technical foul on Layer with 8:11 remaining. Layer was ejected on his second technical with 2:43 left. Glenn Eddy sealed the victory with four free throws in the final 1:14. "We played well," Williams said. "If we play this well all year we'll have a chance to win a lot of games." Colorado led 42-38 at the break despite a limited contribution from Harrison, who was 4-for-6 with nine points in the first half. Colorado State built an 18-9 lead as Freddy Robinson made his first four shots and scored 12 points. But Morandais had four points in an 11-0 run as Colorado pulled ahead 20-18. It was Colorado's fourth straight victory and its fourth straight over Colorado State. This is the best start in the nine years Patton has coached at Colorado. "This was a good test for us," Harrison said. "I'm sure we'll look back on this game and build on it when we play a team similar to Colorado State that has a good big man."
